python101.name: Chapter 6: Conditional Statements (Control Flow)
python101.content: Learn how to control program flow using if, elif, else, nested conditions, ternary expressions, and match-case.

sections.title: What Are Conditional Statements?
sections.content: Conditional statements let your program choose which code to run based on a condition (True/False).

sections.title: if Statement
sections.content:
Run a block only if the condition is True.

```python
temperature = 30

if temperature > 25:
    print("Turn on the AC.")
```

sections.title: Short-Hand if
sections.content:
Single-line if for very simple checks.

```python
score = 95
if score > 90: print("Excellent!")
```

sections.title: if–else
sections.content:
Choose one of two branches.

```python
balance = 120

if balance >= 100:
    print("Order confirmed.")
else:
    print("Insufficient funds.")
```

sections.title: Short-Hand if–else (Ternary Expression)
sections.content:
Compact way to choose a value based on a condition.

Pattern:
```python
result = value_if_true if condition else value_if_false
```

Example:
```python
age = 16
category = "adult" if age >= 18 else "minor"
print(category)  # minor
```

match–case (Python 3.10+)
sections.content:
match–case is like switch in other languages; it matches a value against patterns.

```python
status = 404

match status:
    case 200:
        print("OK")
    case 400 | 404:
        print("Client error")
    case 500:
        print("Server error")
    case _:
        print("Unknown status")
```

`_` is the default case that matches anything.
